C:1

November

Hopkins 18, St. Johns 0
Soldier Boys, Outplayed from Whistle to Whistle, Are Unable to
Score. Our Team Plays a Whirlwind Game that Rushes
Their Annapolis Opponents off Their Feet. A
Record Crowd of 1000 Sees the Game.
Stollenwerck Captain for 1910.
"Oh where, oh where are the soldier boys,
Oh where, oh where can they be?"
-0-

t.

n-

12.

12.

Their widely touted team—that was
running up forty and sixty-odd to
nothing scores and held Navy and
Virginia down to the narrowest of
margins—that very self same wonderful team is buried eighteen feet
deep "in the cold, cold ground." The
wildest dreams of the most enthusiastic Hopkins rooter were as nothing compared to the result, for the
most sanguine optimist dared not
hope that we would send the orange
and black team back to Annapolis
without its having scored. On parer the best judges figured out that
St. John's would probably score with
at least one goal from the field and
very possibly a touchdown within the
first twenty minutes of play and in
the second half they gave Hopkins
two touchdowns and possibly a drop
from Stollenwerck. All of which
merely goes to show the futility of
"dope," for Hopkins got their two
touchdowns, one in each half, and
.
two field goals, while the St. John's
team only got within striking distance once during the entire seventy
minutes, and then failed miserably
in their attempt to score.
St. John's was outplayed at every
point of the game with the possible
exception of punting. In fact, it was
due largely to the clever booting of
Brown, who was called upon time
and time again, that the score did
riot soar higher in our favor. But
as for all other things which go to
make up a football team's play they
were simply out-classed. The critics
have gotten their hooks into our
team this year for three things: -poor
tackling, slowness, and inability to
recover a loose ball. Saturday the
team without exception tackled low,
sure, and so hard that more than
once time had to be taken out for the
tackled one. St. John's has a reputation for the rapidty with which
they run off their plays, but one
could not say that they showed more

speed than our team. They used to
boast that Hopkins never recovered
a fumble, but Saturday it was quite
the other way around, and a pair of
black and blue arms encircled three
fumbled balls to every one held by
a soldier boy.
The forward pass was supposed to
be a feature of the game that St.
John's had developed to great perfection, and it was thanks to this
style of play that they have made
the grand showing that they have
this season. So surely, however, did
our end and secondary defence break
up these plays that not once did they
complete a successful pass. On-side
kicks were much the same sort of
a story. Their double passes, delay
passes and other tricks fooled nobody
but themselves, and often proved
valuable gainers of ground for Hopkins.
We had pinned our faith in the
line smashing ability of our backs.
but we did not expect that they
would walk through for five, eight,
ten and twelve yards at a clip. It
was considered a pretty hopless task
to try and gain around their ends,
but Fulton, who was largely used at
this play, found little trouble in
skirting the wing. Running back
kicks did not prove difficult, for the
interference was quick forming, fast,
and very much to the point. The
help-the-ball-along spirit which has
been so conspicuous this season, added many a good yard to our string.
On several different occassions Mills
was kept on his feet and gaining
ground after two or three leech-like
Johnies had fastened to his legs.
The defence was not far behind the
attack in effectiveness. It did not,
however, have the opportunity for
demonstration, for three quarters of
the time the pig skin was in our
possession, and even when St John's
would get it into their hands they
would kick on the first down. It was
certainly a sight to gladden Hopkins'
eyes to see how our ends got down
under kicks and literally downed the
runner before he had started, while

22

r:TER

1909.

we were brought to our feet twenty
times by the breaking up of some
trick or forward pass. Just how much
class there was to the defence is
shown by the fact that during the
seventy minutes of play St. John's
only made first down seven times.
The only feature that could have
looked good to one in gray uniform
with black facings were the two
• times that the Annapolis team braced and held for downs within the five
yard line and the fine punting of their
freshman end, Brown. Most of the
time the orange and black team
seemed to be way up in the air;
rushed off their feet by our whirlwind play, and surprised into frightened and ineffective desperation.
They were cleanly outplayed and but
slightly outweighted, for the yarns
that we should have an advantage of
fifteen or twenty pounds to the man
was but newspaper chatter. As the
eleven lined up we had the better of
the weight question by about five
pounds, an average that was lowered in the second half when such light
men as Gillet, Waters, and Tappen
were sent in.
Every mother's son who wore the
black and blue on the field played the
of his life and each won for himself
game of his life and won for himself
Hall of Fame (Athletic Division).
Over and above and beyond the victory we can have a extra slice of the
thankful bird next Thursday because
though a couple of the squad, Bridgman, Fulton and Peiper particularly,
were in battered condition, still there
is not a scratch or a bruise to show
that anyone played in Saturday's
wonderful game. In fact, if we do
not count Stevenson's new jersey,
time was only taken out once for a
Hopkins man. From such a collection of players it is indeed difficult
to pick stars and it is a foolish custom that makes a football report incomplete without a list of those who
"featured for Hopkins," as the papers
say. Every man played well, but
those who played "wellest" were Stollenwerck, Fulton, Morton, Bridgman,
Mills, and McCabe.
Stollenwerck ran his team like
clock work and he certainly had his
head on his shoulders the right way.
He carried the ball back from kicks
in a style that made the stand fairly
howl, while catching punts seemed to
him like holding four aces pat, and
his drop kicking netted us six points.
His generalship, drop kicking, and
running in a broken field made him
just about our "one best" and his
election as captain for next year is
a well deserved honor.
Pillion was another star. His fifty-five yard run round end was one

Price, 5 cents per copy.
of the most sensational plays of the
game, and it placed the ball where
Mills could carry it over the line in
*the next play. Jack repeatedly made
big gains round end, in fact he probably carried the ball a greater distance than any other man on the
team. Morton at end proved himself
a real hero. He was swift as a greyhound and keen as a hawk, while his
tackling was sure and hard. Bridgman, "the old reliable Ev," did his
usual stunts when given the ball. The
interference he gave Stony was wonderful and the way he put the curse
on forward passes was in itself
enough to make him everlastingly famous. Musser was another who was
strictly on the sketch all the time.
Again and again he got through the
line and his tackling was decidedly a
feature. Mills ploughed through the
St. John's linemen ss if they had been
a big box of lead soldiers, and the
way he backed up the line was
"something scrumptious." Captain
Dick at the pivotal position was a
tower of strength to the line and his
accurate passing of the ball to Fulton prevented a recurrance of the
costly fumble of last year.
"Revenge is sweet" and the Hopkins cohorts went wild with joy when
the blowing of the whistle announced
that the game was over, while over
on the score board big black letters
told the result of Hopkins 18, St.
John's o. The best team that St.
John's has had in years was downed
by two touchdowns, two goals and
two field goals, and wers not even
given a word to say in the final score.
The contest attracted the biggest
crowd ever gathered together at a
football game in Baltimore, and many
of the former classes came out in a
body. Probably there was never
such an outpouring of grads and never was there such enthusiasm among
the undergraduates. Every one turned out and th,, singing and cheering
was the best in years.
Saturday night was Hopkins night
not only at Ford's, but also all over
the city. The whole town was black
and blue and at every place where
one buys eats and drinks a party of
Hopkins men could be found celebrating the great victory.
At Ford's Hattie Williams played
"Detective Sparks"to a house trimmed
with Hopkins banners and filled with
Hopkins rooters.
The team sat in the boxes and their
enthusiastic supporters amused themselves and the others in the house by
cheering the eleven, the leading lady,
themselves and T. H. U. The show
was good and every one who went
certainly had a fitting ending for a
glorious day.

now in the patent department of the
General Electric Company.

was married on November 9 to Miss
Marie Worthington.

The Rev. Lyman P. Powell, 1890,
rector of St. John's Church, Northhampton, Mass., has recently published two new books—"Heavenly Heretics" and "The Emmanuel Movement."
Professor Mitsakuri, Ph.D., '82,
professor of zoology at University of
Tokyo, died September 17, 1909.
E. C. Sanford, Ph.D., '88, has recently been elected president of Clark
College, Worcester, Mass.
Albert Bernhardt Faust, '89, Ph.D.
'92, professor of German at Cornell,
has recently published a work in two
volumes, entitled "The German Element in the United States."

Thomas G. Machen, 'o6, graduated
last year from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He is now in
Baltimore.
W. Watters Pagon, '05, is studying at the Massachusetts Institute of
Technology.

A letLer published today in our columns g.ves voice to another protest
against football fatalities. Sinoe the
receipt of this letter we have heard
with sorrow of the death of still another football player—Mr. Christian
of Virginia. It is unfortunate that
the rues of football have not been
so moderated as to reduce the likelihood of serious injury. Baseball, lacrosse, and other games are played
constantly without danger to the participants, but scarcely any college
footl all game takes place without
someone receiving painful, if not
As a college
dangerous injuries.
game, football will surely continue
for many years, but it is to be hoped
that a movement will soon manifest
itself among colleges to moderate the
rules so as to render the game less
dangerous. There is a feeling among

then, are surely worth while, and
we trust they will be repeated on similar occasions.

PROF. BACON LECTURES
+++++
In McCoy Hall last Tuesday afternoon, Prof. Benjamin W. Bacon, of
Yale University gave a very interesting lecture on "The Greek Cities
of Palestine at the Beginning of Our
Era." The lecture was held under
the auspices of the Baltimore Society
of the Archaeological Institute of
America and it was illustrated with
numerous stereopticon views taken by
Prof. Bacon during his residence in
Palestine while at the head of the
American School there.

HOPKINS CLUB ELECTS
OFFICERS
At the annual election of officers
of the Johns Hopkins Club on Saturday night, November 13, the officers for the past year were all reelected. They are as folloWs: Benjamin F. Cator, president; Dr. William
H. Howell, vice president; Dr. Phil;p
Ogden. secretary, and Dr. George
E. Barnett, treasurer. Prof. W. W.
Willoughby, W. D. Lilly, B. Howell
Griswold, Jr., were reelected members of the board of governors of the
club. R. Curzon Hoffman, Jr., was
chosen to fill a vacancy on the
board. The Board of Governors for
the ensuing year consists of Dr. Wil-

MASS MEETING
1111+

The first of a series of mass meetings was held in Hopkins Hall last
Monday at five o'clock for the purpose of increasing the already overflowing enthusiasm of the students
for the coming football game with
St. John's. Three of the alumni were
present—Dr. Thomas M. Brown, Mr.
George Radcliffe, and Mr. Curzon
Hoffman, Jr.—and made brief speeches showing the interest that they felt
in the annual contest and explaining
the extra energy that they were exerting this year to get a large body

of the alumni out to root. The class
of 1903 is planning to come out in
a body, and, no doubt, others will do
likewise. Subscriptions were solicited for a band, and, judging from
the way money has been coming in, a
band will be on hand much larger
than that of last year.
The game was advertised in a
show window on Baltimore street—
N. W. Haynes asked for any suggestions that the students might offer as

INTERSCOLASTIC GAME AT
HOMEWOOD
One of the most important interscholastic games in Baltimore was
played at Homewood last Thursday
afternoon. The schools represented
were Dunham's and the Country
School for Boys. The latter won after a plucky fight against a much
heavier team. The crowd was very
large, fully half of the grandstand
Many persons were
being filled.

The mass meetings were continued
through the week and were of great
service in familiarizing the freshmen
with the University songs.

Dr. Robert Wood, of the Physics
Department, is one of a committee
of scientists who are to investigate
the occult powers claimed by the Italian spiritualist Signora Eusapia Pal-

ladino.
The "Scrubs" defeated the first
team of The Boys' Latin School on
Saturday morning, November 6. The
score was very close, being 6 to 5.
Although the weather was threatening, a large crowd of rooters were
on hand to encourage their respective
players.

THE NEWS-LETTER
Y. M. C. A.

C. & P. St. Paul 967
Md., Courtland 900

+++44
The St. John's game is over. Let
it rest for an hour. Dr. Kirk speaks
in Levering Hall, Monday at five
.eclock, so come to hear him.
Dr. Kirk, himself a college man, is
:an exceptionally good speaker to students and we hope a large crowd will
,be present.
This meeting is the first of our
°series of meetings for this year. In
December, Dr. Finney will give two
-talks on the subject of impurity. Every student check off in his Handbook December 6th and loth, the
-dates of Dr. Finney's meetings.
Chapel services had a large attendance this week.
Nevertheless the
room was not uncomfortably crowded
:and we are looking for a higher average this week.
The Student Volunteer Band is
pursuing studies upon the unoccupied
fields of the world. The meetings
are very interesting and should any
-one espececially interested in missions desire to attend, the Volunteers
would be glad to extend a welcome.
Don't forget to use the Handbook
slips whenever possible. It helps us
and does not inconvenience you.

C:1

November

Hopkins 18, St. Johns 0
Soldier Boys, Outplayed from Whistle to Whistle, Are Unable to
Score. Our Team Plays a Whirlwind Game that Rushes
Their Annapolis Opponents off Their Feet. A
Record Crowd of 1000 Sees the Game.
Stollenwerck Captain for 1910.
"Oh where, oh where are the soldier boys,
Oh where, oh where can they be?"
-0-

t.

n-

12.

12.

Their widely touted team—that was
running up forty and sixty-odd to
nothing scores and held Navy and
Virginia down to the narrowest of
margins—that very self same wonderful team is buried eighteen feet
deep "in the cold, cold ground." The
wildest dreams of the most enthusiastic Hopkins rooter were as nothing compared to the result, for the
most sanguine optimist dared not
hope that we would send the orange
and black team back to Annapolis
without its having scored. On parer the best judges figured out that
St. John's would probably score with
at least one goal from the field and
very possibly a touchdown within the
first twenty minutes of play and in
the second half they gave Hopkins
two touchdowns and possibly a drop
from Stollenwerck. All of which
merely goes to show the futility of
"dope," for Hopkins got their two
touchdowns, one in each half, and
.
two field goals, while the St. John's
team only got within striking distance once during the entire seventy
minutes, and then failed miserably
in their attempt to score.
St. John's was outplayed at every
point of the game with the possible
exception of punting. In fact, it was
due largely to the clever booting of
Brown, who was called upon time
and time again, that the score did
riot soar higher in our favor. But
as for all other things which go to
make up a football team's play they
were simply out-classed. The critics
have gotten their hooks into our
team this year for three things: -poor
tackling, slowness, and inability to
recover a loose ball. Saturday the
team without exception tackled low,
sure, and so hard that more than
once time had to be taken out for the
tackled one. St. John's has a reputation for the rapidty with which
they run off their plays, but one
could not say that they showed more

speed than our team. They used to
boast that Hopkins never recovered
a fumble, but Saturday it was quite
the other way around, and a pair of
black and blue arms encircled three
fumbled balls to every one held by
a soldier boy.
The forward pass was supposed to
be a feature of the game that St.
John's had developed to great perfection, and it was thanks to this
style of play that they have made
the grand showing that they have
this season. So surely, however, did
our end and secondary defence break
up these plays that not once did they
complete a successful pass. On-side
kicks were much the same sort of
a story. Their double passes, delay
passes and other tricks fooled nobody
but themselves, and often proved
valuable gainers of ground for Hopkins.
We had pinned our faith in the
line smashing ability of our backs.
but we did not expect that they
would walk through for five, eight,
ten and twelve yards at a clip. It
was considered a pretty hopless task
to try and gain around their ends,
but Fulton, who was largely used at
this play, found little trouble in
skirting the wing. Running back
kicks did not prove difficult, for the
interference was quick forming, fast,
and very much to the point. The
help-the-ball-along spirit which has
been so conspicuous this season, added many a good yard to our string.
On several different occassions Mills
was kept on his feet and gaining
ground after two or three leech-like
Johnies had fastened to his legs.
The defence was not far behind the
attack in effectiveness. It did not,
however, have the opportunity for
demonstration, for three quarters of
the time the pig skin was in our
possession, and even when St John's
would get it into their hands they
would kick on the first down. It was
certainly a sight to gladden Hopkins'
eyes to see how our ends got down
under kicks and literally downed the
runner before he had started, while

22

r:TER

1909.

we were brought to our feet twenty
times by the breaking up of some
trick or forward pass. Just how much
class there was to the defence is
shown by the fact that during the
seventy minutes of play St. John's
only made first down seven times.
The only feature that could have
looked good to one in gray uniform
with black facings were the two
• times that the Annapolis team braced and held for downs within the five
yard line and the fine punting of their
freshman end, Brown. Most of the
time the orange and black team
seemed to be way up in the air;
rushed off their feet by our whirlwind play, and surprised into frightened and ineffective desperation.
They were cleanly outplayed and but
slightly outweighted, for the yarns
that we should have an advantage of
fifteen or twenty pounds to the man
was but newspaper chatter. As the
eleven lined up we had the better of
the weight question by about five
pounds, an average that was lowered in the second half when such light
men as Gillet, Waters, and Tappen
were sent in.
Every mother's son who wore the
black and blue on the field played the
of his life and each won for himself
game of his life and won for himself
Hall of Fame (Athletic Division).
Over and above and beyond the victory we can have a extra slice of the
thankful bird next Thursday because
though a couple of the squad, Bridgman, Fulton and Peiper particularly,
were in battered condition, still there
is not a scratch or a bruise to show
that anyone played in Saturday's
wonderful game. In fact, if we do
not count Stevenson's new jersey,
time was only taken out once for a
Hopkins man. From such a collection of players it is indeed difficult
to pick stars and it is a foolish custom that makes a football report incomplete without a list of those who
"featured for Hopkins," as the papers
say. Every man played well, but
those who played "wellest" were Stollenwerck, Fulton, Morton, Bridgman,
Mills, and McCabe.
Stollenwerck ran his team like
clock work and he certainly had his
head on his shoulders the right way.
He carried the ball back from kicks
in a style that made the stand fairly
howl, while catching punts seemed to
him like holding four aces pat, and
his drop kicking netted us six points.
His generalship, drop kicking, and
running in a broken field made him
just about our "one best" and his
election as captain for next year is
a well deserved honor.
Pillion was another star. His fifty-five yard run round end was one

Price, 5 cents per copy.
of the most sensational plays of the
game, and it placed the ball where
Mills could carry it over the line in
*the next play. Jack repeatedly made
big gains round end, in fact he probably carried the ball a greater distance than any other man on the
team. Morton at end proved himself
a real hero. He was swift as a greyhound and keen as a hawk, while his
tackling was sure and hard. Bridgman, "the old reliable Ev," did his
usual stunts when given the ball. The
interference he gave Stony was wonderful and the way he put the curse
on forward passes was in itself
enough to make him everlastingly famous. Musser was another who was
strictly on the sketch all the time.
Again and again he got through the
line and his tackling was decidedly a
feature. Mills ploughed through the
St. John's linemen ss if they had been
a big box of lead soldiers, and the
way he backed up the line was
"something scrumptious." Captain
Dick at the pivotal position was a
tower of strength to the line and his
accurate passing of the ball to Fulton prevented a recurrance of the
costly fumble of last year.
"Revenge is sweet" and the Hopkins cohorts went wild with joy when
the blowing of the whistle announced
that the game was over, while over
on the score board big black letters
told the result of Hopkins 18, St.
John's o. The best team that St.
John's has had in years was downed
by two touchdowns, two goals and
two field goals, and wers not even
given a word to say in the final score.
The contest attracted the biggest
crowd ever gathered together at a
football game in Baltimore, and many
of the former classes came out in a
body. Probably there was never
such an outpouring of grads and never was there such enthusiasm among
the undergraduates. Every one turned out and th,, singing and cheering
was the best in years.
Saturday night was Hopkins night
not only at Ford's, but also all over
the city. The whole town was black
and blue and at every place where
one buys eats and drinks a party of
Hopkins men could be found celebrating the great victory.
At Ford's Hattie Williams played
"Detective Sparks"to a house trimmed
with Hopkins banners and filled with
Hopkins rooters.
The team sat in the boxes and their
enthusiastic supporters amused themselves and the others in the house by
cheering the eleven, the leading lady,
themselves and T. H. U. The show
was good and every one who went
certainly had a fitting ending for a
glorious day.

A letLer published today in our columns g.ves voice to another protest
against football fatalities. Sinoe the
receipt of this letter we have heard
with sorrow of the death of still another football player—Mr. Christian
of Virginia. It is unfortunate that
the rues of football have not been
so moderated as to reduce the likelihood of serious injury. Baseball, lacrosse, and other games are played
constantly without danger to the participants, but scarcely any college
footl all game takes place without
someone receiving painful, if not
As a college
dangerous injuries.
game, football will surely continue
for many years, but it is to be hoped
that a movement will soon manifest
itself among colleges to moderate the
rules so as to render the game less
dangerous. There is a feeling among

then, are surely worth while, and
we trust they will be repeated on similar occasions.

PROF. BACON LECTURES
+++++
In McCoy Hall last Tuesday afternoon, Prof. Benjamin W. Bacon, of
Yale University gave a very interesting lecture on "The Greek Cities
of Palestine at the Beginning of Our
Era." The lecture was held under
the auspices of the Baltimore Society
of the Archaeological Institute of
America and it was illustrated with
numerous stereopticon views taken by
Prof. Bacon during his residence in
Palestine while at the head of the
American School there.

HOPKINS CLUB ELECTS
OFFICERS
At the annual election of officers
of the Johns Hopkins Club on Saturday night, November 13, the officers for the past year were all reelected. They are as folloWs: Benjamin F. Cator, president; Dr. William
H. Howell, vice president; Dr. Phil;p
Ogden. secretary, and Dr. George
E. Barnett, treasurer. Prof. W. W.
Willoughby, W. D. Lilly, B. Howell
Griswold, Jr., were reelected members of the board of governors of the
club. R. Curzon Hoffman, Jr., was
chosen to fill a vacancy on the
board. The Board of Governors for
the ensuing year consists of Dr. Wil-

MASS MEETING
1111+

The first of a series of mass meetings was held in Hopkins Hall last
Monday at five o'clock for the purpose of increasing the already overflowing enthusiasm of the students
for the coming football game with
St. John's. Three of the alumni were
present—Dr. Thomas M. Brown, Mr.
George Radcliffe, and Mr. Curzon
Hoffman, Jr.—and made brief speeches showing the interest that they felt
in the annual contest and explaining
the extra energy that they were exerting this year to get a large body

of the alumni out to root. The class
of 1903 is planning to come out in
a body, and, no doubt, others will do
likewise. Subscriptions were solicited for a band, and, judging from
the way money has been coming in, a
band will be on hand much larger
than that of last year.
The game was advertised in a
show window on Baltimore street—
N. W. Haynes asked for any suggestions that the students might offer as

INTERSCOLASTIC GAME AT
HOMEWOOD
One of the most important interscholastic games in Baltimore was
played at Homewood last Thursday
afternoon. The schools represented
were Dunham's and the Country
School for Boys. The latter won after a plucky fight against a much
heavier team. The crowd was very
large, fully half of the grandstand
Many persons were
being filled.

The mass meetings were continued
through the week and were of great
service in familiarizing the freshmen
with the University songs.

Dr. Robert Wood, of the Physics
Department, is one of a committee
of scientists who are to investigate
the occult powers claimed by the Italian spiritualist Signora Eusapia Pal-

ladino.
The "Scrubs" defeated the first
team of The Boys' Latin School on
Saturday morning, November 6. The
score was very close, being 6 to 5.
Although the weather was threatening, a large crowd of rooters were
on hand to encourage their respective
players.

THE NEWS-LETTER
Y. M. C. A.

C. & P. St. Paul 967
Md., Courtland 900

+++44
The St. John's game is over. Let
it rest for an hour. Dr. Kirk speaks
in Levering Hall, Monday at five
.eclock, so come to hear him.
Dr. Kirk, himself a college man, is
:an exceptionally good speaker to students and we hope a large crowd will
,be present.
This meeting is the first of our
°series of meetings for this year. In
December, Dr. Finney will give two
-talks on the subject of impurity. Every student check off in his Handbook December 6th and loth, the
-dates of Dr. Finney's meetings.
Chapel services had a large attendance this week.
Nevertheless the
room was not uncomfortably crowded
:and we are looking for a higher average this week.
The Student Volunteer Band is
pursuing studies upon the unoccupied
fields of the world. The meetings
are very interesting and should any
-one espececially interested in missions desire to attend, the Volunteers
would be glad to extend a welcome.
Don't forget to use the Handbook
slips whenever possible. It helps us
and does not inconvenience you.
